The notes I've posted on this website are supplements to STAT-UB 103, an introductory course in modern statistical methods for analysis and model building. For demonstrations I've used R, a popular choice of programming language for statistical work (but one among many). The first three chapters are a pithy introduction to the R environment.  

I've tried to make the notes accessible and relevant--but in the dueness of course it may become apparent that I cannot fully be absolved of occasional mediocrity. Feedback is thus most welcome--please get in touch or submit a pull request on <a href="https://github.com/vaabe/stats103">Github</a>.   

Further textbooks/references you should check out:

- <a href="https://moderndive.com/">ModernDive</a>
- <a href="https://www.openintro.org/index.php">OpenIntro Statistics</a>
- <a href="https://rafalab.github.io/dsbook/">Introduction to Data Science</a>
- <a href="https://web.stanford.edu/~hastie/ElemStatLearn/">Elements of Statistical Learning</a>

For detailed guides on using the R language:

- <a href="https://r4ds.had.co.nz/">R for Data Science</a>
- <a href="http://adv-r.had.co.nz/">Advanced R</a>
